results.title: Rock & Wrestle for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Firebird Software, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and paper booklet in a plastic cassette case..
results.brief_description:
Rock’n Wrestle (known as Bop’n Wrestle in the US) was one of the first games to have 3D movement through space. The game allowed for single or dual player modes, using the joystick or the keyboard supporting twenty-four wrestling manoeuvres. You could inflict pile drivers, arm-twists and body slams on your opponent. You play as blonde hero, Gorgeous Greg, named for the game’s creator, Gregg Barnett. Each of your ten opponents in the ring has a different personality and a distinctive wrestling style. Energy bars, which get depleted as you exert yourself, monitor your ‘lives’. A round is won when one of the wrestlers is pinned to the floor for three seconds. The next round offers opponents who are tougher than the last.
In addition to the use of characters moving through 3D space, Rock ‘n Wrestle offered a highly innovative set of context based moves. This meant that if a player lifts up another player it would unlocks a set of moves , or if you threw a player against the ropes it unlocks a suitable set of moves to capitalise on their rebound. This game is believed to be the first wrestling game for the home computer. Beam Software later had to turn down an approach by World Wresting Federation (WWF), as they were working on a Sergeant Slaughter title, missing out on being part of the huge, ongoing WWF video games franchise.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/rockn-wrestle-bobn-wrestle/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1985 by Melbourne House and Erbe Software S.A

results.title: Ceiling with scrapite finish
results.creator_credit: Topical Film Company and Brent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
One of a series of four films which gives a basic training in plastering as applied to building construction. The use of expanded metal lathing is demonstrated and the way in which the plaster adheres to it. Three coats are applied, render, float and set. The making of dots and screeds is shown. Before the final coat is applied the cornice is run. The method of cutting the mould for this and the addition of horse and handle is shown. Screeds and running rule are fitted in position and the cornice is run. Finally, the finishing coat is applied to the ceiling.

Before the final coat is applied the cornice is run. The method of cutting the mould for this and the addition of horse and handle is shown. Screeds and running rule are fitted in position and the cornice is run. Finally, the finishing coat is applied to the ceiling.

group_siblings.title: Cornice mould and fibrous plaster cast

results.title: Cornice mould and fibrous plaster cast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
The architect’s drawing, paper template, zinc template, stock and horse - these are the stages that produce the tool that the plasterer will use. The stages of forming the mould are demonstrated in detail, the core and the final coat without muffle.

results.title: Exterior wall with tyrolean finish
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
This first coat consists of a water repellent cement. Materials and their proportions are stated. The surface is scratched to provide a key for the next coat. This second coat is applied with the help of dots and screeds to ensure a true vertical surface. The formation of a plinth is demonstrated. This is made in two stages, core and finishing coat. The wall itself may be finished in various ways. Three different kinds of finishing coats are shows: Tyrolean finish, pebble dash, and rough cast.
results.description:

results.title: Delegating work
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Illustrates the problem of a supervisor’s failure to delegate work and the serious effect on his efficiency.

results.title: The Trouble with women
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Historically interesting film - to be taken in context to the year it was produced, ie the 1950’s! A supervisor, Brad, discusses his objections to a new woman worker with the Personnel Manager. He recalls trouble with previous women employees: one kept her desk like a dressing table and objected to moving to a different one; another engaged girl gave insufficient notice of leaving to marry; then there was absenteeism. The Personnel Manager suggests that it is up to Brad whether the new “girl” adds up to trouble. The audience is asked: “What is Brad’s trouble?” Useful for feminist theory studies.

results.title: The Personal problem
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Shows that a supervisor who avoids discussing an employee’s personal problem with him may cause a production fall-off by the worker.
